topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Jessica Livingston, her role as YC co-founder, and frames the episode around her "Social Radar" ability to read founders and people dynamics.

topics.title: Being erased and credit for founding YC
topics.summary: Jessica discusses being left out of YC narratives (media/Wikipedia), why it happens, and why she personally doesn’t dwell on external validation—while noting how omission can serve certain narratives about YC.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Enterpret and Anvil.

topics.title: What "Social Radar" means at YC
topics.summary: Jessica explains how she evaluated founders through social cues during 10-minute YC interviews—co-founder dynamics, commitment, and subtle red flags—complementing her technical co-founders’ focus.

topics.title: Avoiding assholes and building YC culture
topics.summary: They discuss why YC sometimes avoided funding overtly difficult personalities, especially early on, and how that helped shape a supportive alumni culture where founders help each other.

topics.title: Application and interview red flags
topics.summary: Jessica details what she flagged in applications (equity splits, job commitment, cap table oddities) and in interviews (defensiveness, co-founder control issues, "hacker in a cage" dynamics).

topics.title: Defensiveness vs open-mindedness in founders
topics.summary: Jessica explains why defensiveness predicts failure: founders must handle skepticism, learn quickly, and adapt to user reality; the best founders treat questioning as collaborative problem-solving.

topics.title: Airbnb interview: hustlers and founder bet
topics.summary: Jessica recounts the Airbnb interview: YC disliked the idea but loved the founders’ energy and scrappiness, highlighted by the Obama O’s/Cap’n McCain’s stunt, leading to a strong founder-based bet.

topics.title: More founder-bet stories: GOAT and others
topics.summary: Jessica shares how certain interviews made her confident in founders regardless of idea, including GOAT’s founders (then Grubwithus) and the importance of domain insight even in unsexy markets.

topics.title: Charisma, domain expertise, and earnestness
topics.summary: They distinguish useful charisma from empty salesmanship, emphasize domain expertise, and introduce "earnestness"/authenticity as a key signal—illustrated by a non-credible "teen fashion" app example.

topics.title: Confidence and commitment: quitting and co-founder fit
topics.summary: Jessica contrasts confidence with defensiveness, explains why founders must eventually "burn the boat" (quit jobs), and why co-founder relationship quality/history is critical given how often disputes kill startups.

topics.title: Origins of her people-reading ability
topics.summary: Jessica describes lifelong curiosity about people and motives ("Detective Livingston"), how she notices anomalies and dislikes phoniness, and demonstrates it by inferring why Lenny added a podcast disclaimer.

topics.title: Validating instincts, being fooled, and YC tooling
topics.summary: She explains how she sanity-checks gut instincts over years, admits occasional misses (including a founder later convicted of major crypto theft), and describes YC’s application flagging system for common risks.

topics.title: How to develop a "social radar" checklist
topics.summary: Jessica offers practical guidance: consciously watch for subtle cues, ask direct questions about co-founder history and commitment, and use a simple mental checklist (defensiveness, alignment, product understanding).
